Article Microenvironment engineering of nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres encapsulated with Pd catalysts for highly selective hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived vanillin in water Jun Wu a * Liqian Liu a Xinyue Yan a Gang Pan a Jiahao Bai a Chengbing Wang a Fuwei Li b * Yong Li a * a School of Materials Science & Engineering, Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Green Preparation and Functionalization for Inorganic Materials, Shaanxi University of Science & Technology, Xi'an 710021, Shaanxi, China School of Materials Science & Engineering Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Green Preparation and Functionalization for Inorganic Materials Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi'an Shaanxi 710021 China School of Materials Science & Engineering, Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Green Preparation and Functionalization for Inorganic Materials, Shaanxi University of Science & Technology, Xi'an 710021, Shaanxi, China b School of Chemical Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China School of Chemical Engineering University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China School of Chemical Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China * Corresponding author. Development of efficient and stable metal catalysts for the selective aqueous phase hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of biomass-derived oxygenates to value-added biofuels is highly desired. An innovative surface microenvironment modulation strategy was used to construct the nitrogen-doped hollow carbon sphere encapsulated with Pd (Pd@NHCS-X, X: 600–800) nanoreactors for catalytic HDO of biomass-derived vanillin in water. The specific surface microenvironments of Pd@NHCS catalysts including the electronic property of active Pd centers and the surface wettability and porous structure of NHCS supports could be well-controlled by the calcination temperature of catalysts. Intrinsic kinetic evaluations demonstrated that the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented a high turnover frequency of 337.77 h–1 and a low apparent activation energy of 18.63 kJ/mol. The excellent catalytic HDO performance was attributed to the unique surface microenvironment of Pd@NHCS catalyst based on structure-performance relationship analysis and DFT calculations. It revealed that pyridinic N species dominated the electronic property regulation of Pd sites through electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) and produced numerous electron-rich active Pd centers, which not only intensified the dissociation and activation of H2 molecules, but also substantially improved the activation capability of vanillin via the enhanced adsorption of –C=O group. The fine hydrophilicity and abundant porous structure promoted the uniform dispersion of catalyst and ensured the effective access of reactants to catalytic active centers in water. Additionally, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic stability and broad substrate applicability for the selective aqueous phase HDO of various biomass-derived carbonyl compounds. The proposed surface microenvironment modulation strategy will provide a new consideration for the rational design of high- performance nitrogen-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts for catalytic biomass transformation. Graphical Abstract An innovative surface microenvironment modulation strategy was used to construct nitrogen-doped hollow carbon sphere encapsulated with Pd (Pd@NHCS) nanoreactors, which presented excellent catalytic hydrodeoxygenation performance for biomass-derived vanillin under mild atmospheric reaction conditions in water. Keywords Microenvironment modulation Nitrogen-doped hollow carbon sphere Pd-based catalyst Electronic metal-support interaction Hydrodeoxygenation Vanillin 1 Introduction Catalytic upgrading of lignocellulosic biomass into value-added chemicals and fuels has attracted increasing attention due to the energy shortages and environmental concerns caused by the extensive utilization of fossil fuels. Bio-oil, derived from the pyrolysis of biomass, is a type of renewable clean energy and usually contains high oxygen content of up to 60% [1]. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an effective strategy to upgrade bio-oil that can enhance energy density and stability through the selective cleavage of –C–O bonds [2]. Notably, supported metals catalyzed HDO of vanillin, a typical lignin-based model compound, leads to the formation of valuable 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP) [3–8], which has been widely applied in the fuel, spice, and pharmaceutical industries. Moreover, the efficient implementation of this HDO reaction process depends heavily on the design and development of high-performance supported metal catalysts through the rational modulation of the composition and structure of active metal centers and supports [9–11]. Owing to the HDO reaction generally occurring on the surface of heterogeneous catalysts, the surface microenvironment of supported metal catalyst dominates the interaction between reactants and catalyst, and plays a crucial role in the catalytic HDO performance [12,13]. Generally, the surface microenvironment of supported metal catalyst is closely related to the characteristic of support and the electronic structure of active metal centers. Up to now, special efforts have been focused on regulating the surface microenvironments of supported metal catalysts for biomass HDO in different ways such as the enhancement of particle dispersion of active metal centers [14], the modulation of metal-support interaction [15], the regulation of the wettability and acidity/basicity of supports [16,17]. As for the supported metal catalysts, high particle dispersion can enhance the atom utilization and generate abundant low-coordinated active sites [18], thus promoting the surface adsorption and activation of reactants. For example, the increased metal dispersion enhanced the catalytic HDO activity over the biochar-supported Pd catalyst [19], which induced the HDO of vanillin to produce MMP with a 92% selectivity under the conditions of 100 °C and 3 MPa H2. Notably, the interfacial charge transfers between metal species and the support originated from the electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI), which not only can stabilize and disperse the supported metal particles, but also regulate the electronic structure of active metal centers, further enhancing the catalytic performance [20–23]. Moreover, the introduction of heteroatom or defect in support may usually induce strong EMSI in supported metal catalysts [24,25]. It has been reported that the vacancy-affluent h-BN and WO2.72 could generate a strong atomic interface electron transfer between the supported Ru and Pd single atoms through the EMSI [26,27], leading to the enhancement of catalytic activity for vanillin HDO. In addition, the surface wettability of supports in the reaction medium often affects the catalytic HDO activity. Especially for the aqueous phase HDO of vanillin, good hydrophilicity was the precondition to ensure the well-dispersion of supported metal catalysts in the water medium, which can promote the effective contact between reactant and catalytic active sites and enhance the catalytic activity [28]. Zhou and Cai et al. investigated the effects of the wettability of the carbonaceous microspheres supported Pd and the cellulose-supported PdNi alloy catalysts on the aqueous phase HDO performance of vanillin [29,30]. It was found that the more hydrophilic catalysts were more catalytically active for the aqueous phase hydrodeoxygenation of vanillin due to the good dispersion and enhanced adsorption of reactant molecules on catalytic active sites. Nevertheless, the existing supported metal catalyst systems are difficult to achieve the synergistic regulation of the electronic properties of active metal centers and the wettability of supports, which usually leads to the unsatisfactory catalytic activity for vanillin HDO. Moreover, the relatively high reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure pose a major challenge to the stability of supported metal catalysts, especially in the aqueous phase HDO reaction. In addition, the harsh reaction environment easily induces the side reactions such as the over-hydrogenolysis and the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring [31]. Thereby, the development of efficient and stable supported metal catalysts with precisely tailored surface microenvironments using the simple and controllable modulation approach is highly urgent and desirable for the selective HDO of lignin-based vanillin to MMP in the green solvent of water. Nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres (NHCS) encapsulated with metal catalysts have recently attracted enormous research interests in biomass HDO reactions [32]. Their unique surface microenvironment effects could strengthen the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts through the targeted design of hollow nanoreactors [33]. The chemical composition and porous structure of the NHCS support not only can modify the wettability and acidity/basicity properties of the support surface [34,35], but also effectively tune the distribution and, more importantly, the electronic structure of active metal centers through the strong metal-support interaction [24], thus realizing the directional modulation of surface microenvironment. Notably, the introduction of N atoms on the surface of the hollow carbon sphere can produce the electronic metal-support interaction, and facilitate the formation of active metal centers with tailorable electronic structure and d-band center [36], which plays a significant role in determining the catalytic activity and selectivity of NHCS encapsulated with metal catalysts. Additionally, the presence of N atoms will regulate the surface wettability of NHCS support and endow the supported metal catalysts with proper hydrophilicity, thereby leading to the fine dispersion of catalysts in aqueous solution and the promoted access of reactant molecules to catalytic active centers [37]. Moreover, the abundant pore structures in the NHCS shell and the hollow cavity provide the confined space to stabilize and disperse the metal nanoparticles (NPs), and favor the formation of active metal centers with high particle dispersion and narrow size distribution, which is mainly responsible for the enhanced catalytic stability [38,39]. However, it should be noted that the introduction of N atoms into the carbon support usually results in the simultaneous doping of various nitrogen species (e.g. pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and N-oxide) due to the similar nitrogen species generation energy [37,40]. It is still so difficult to precisely discern which nitrogen species dominates the EMSI between NHCS support and active metal centers, and finally determines the catalytic performance of encapsulated metal centers. Considering the unique advantage of nitrogen-doped hollow carbon sphere in tuning the EMSI and the wettability and stabilizing the active metal nanoparticles, it is worthwhile and challenging to develop high-performance nitrogen-doped hollow carbon sphere encapsulated with metal catalyst with specific surface microenvironment through rational design of the chemical composition and structure of hollow nanoreactors, to accurately reveal the correlation between surface microenvironment and the catalytic HDO performance of vanillin in water. Herein, we developed a series of nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres encapsulated with Pd catalysts (Pd@NHCS-X, X = 600–800) with tunable surface microenvironments using the SiO2 template-directed polymerization of dopamine accompanied by the introduction of palladium source. The surface microenvironment of Pd@NHCS catalyst could be effectively regulated by the calcination temperature of catalyst. A proper calcination temperature might not only produce suitable hydrophilicity and abundant porous structure in the Pd@NHCS catalysts, but also could control the type and content of surface nitrogen species, realizing the precise modification of surface electronic property of active Pd centers via the EMSI. The obtained Pd@NHCS catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability in the aqueous phase HDO of vanillin to synthesize MMP under the mild atmospheric reaction conditions. Systematic structure characterizations and intrinsic catalytic kinetic evaluations were conducted to study the surface microenvironment effect and reveal the relationship of structure-performance of Pd@NHCS catalysts for vanillin HDO reaction. Moreover, DFT calculations were used to elucidate the dominant role of pyridinic N species in tuning the electronic structure of active Pd centers, and the corresponding reaction mechanism was proposed. In addition, the scalability experiments and the substrate scope of Pd@NHCS catalyst in various biomass-derived carbonyl compounds were investigated. This work provides novel insights into the development of efficient and stable nitrogen-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts through the surface microenvironment modulation strategy for aqueous phase HDO of biomass-derived oxygen-containing compounds. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Vanillin (C8H8O3), vanillyl alcohol (C8H10O3), 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (C8H10O2), o-vanillin (C8H8O3), ethylvanillin (C9H10O3), isovanillin (C8H8O3), anisic aldehyde (C8H8O2) and benzaldehyde (C7H6O), cinnamaldehyde (C9H8O) and furfural (C5H4O2), acetophenone (C8H8O) and 4-hydroxyacetophenone (C8H8O2) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (C8H20O4Si, TEOS), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), aqueous ammonia (NH3·H2O), dopamine hydrochloride (C8H11NO2·HCl), potassium tetrachloropalladate (K2PdCl4), chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6), ruthenium (III) chloride (RuCl3), copper nitrate hydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Various solvents including methanol (CH4O), ethanol (C2H6O), isopropanol (C3H8O), n-propanol (C3H8O), 1,4-dioxane (C4H8O2), and toluene (C7H8) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of SiO2 nanospheres The hard templates of SiO2 nanospheres were synthesized using the Stöber method. Typically, 11.2 mL of TEOS was dissolved in the mixture solution containing the ethanol (117 g), water (20 g), and NH3·H2O (7 g). Then this mixture was subjected to vigorous stirring at room temperature for 6 h. After the completion of reaction, the above mixture solution was centrifuged and washed with water and ethanol for several times. The obtained SiO2 nanospheres were collected and dried at 60 °C overnight. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Pd@NHCS and other comparison catalysts The nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres encapsulated with Pd catalysts (Pd@NHCS) were synthesized through the SiO2 hard template-directed the polymerization of dopamine (DA) along with the simultaneous introduction of palladium source. A specific synthesis procedure of the Pd@NHCS catalyst was as follows: firstly, 500 mg of SiO2 nanospheres was dispersed in 50 mL of Tris buffer solution for 1 h. Then 500 mg of dopamine hydrochloride was added to the mixture solution. After stirring for 0.5 h, K2PdCl4 was added into the above solution and vigorously stirred for 24 h at room temperature. After the polymerization reaction was completed, the as-obtained suspension was centrifugated and washed with water and ethanol several times. Subsequently, the precipitate of PdCl4 2–-PDA@SiO2 was obtained after drying at a vacuum drying oven under 60 °C overnight. After the PdCl4 2–-PDA@SiO2 precursor carbonized at 600–800 °C (10 °C/min) for 1 h in the tube heating furnace under 10% H2/N2 atmosphere, the corresponding Pd@NCS@SiO2 composite was obtained. Then the above carbonized sample was ultrasonically dispersed into 5 M NaOH aqueous solution at 60 °C for 6 h. After removing the SiO2 templates, the Pd@NHCS-X (X = 600–800) catalyst was collected by centrifuging and washing with water and dried at a vacuum drying oven under 60 °C overnight. Besides, to investigate the effect of Pd loading on catalytic HDO performance, a series of Pd@NHCS-600-Y catalysts (Y indicates the mass percentage content of Pd, Y = 0.6, 2.8, 3.5, 5.7, 6.3) with different Pd loadings were prepared using the above similar synthesis process through regulating the content of K2PdCl4 added. The Pd@NHCS-600 denoted the catalyst with a Pd loading of 6.3 wt% unless otherwise specified. In addition, the synthesis process of the NHCS catalyst was similar to that of the Pd@NHCS catalyst as described in the above section except that without the addition of palladium source. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Max-2200PC) was used to analyze the phase composition and crystal structure of various catalysts, which was recorded in the θ–2θ mode on a D8 Focus diffractometer, operated at 40 kV and 40 mA within scattering angels of 10°–85°. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, VECTOR22) was used to measure the surface functional groups of various catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250xi) was used to investigate the surface compositions and electronic properties of various catalysts, and all results were calibrated by a C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. The defect structure and graphitic degree of various catalysts were studied using Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw-India). The specific surface area and the pore size distribution of various catalysts were measured on a Mike ASAP2020 instrument. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Norwalk, CT, USA) was used to determine the Pd content. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of various catalysts were recorded on an instrument of FEI Verios 460. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images, and elemental mappings were recorded on an instrument of FEI Tecnai G2 F20 under 200 kV. The quantitative adsorption tests of vanillin and vanillyl alcohol on various catalysts were conducted using the ultraviolet and visible spectrophotometer (UV-vis, Agilent, Cary 5000). The thermal decomposition process of the catalyst precursor was characterized by the thermo-gravimetric analysis instrument (TG, Q500). The dynamic contact angles of various catalysts were measured on an instrument of FCA200A. H2 temperature‐programmed desorption (H2‐TPD) tests were conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem Ⅱ 2920 adsorption instrument, which was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In a typical H2-TPD test, a 30 mg sample was initially enclosed and purged within a reactor under the He atmosphere at 250 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the reactor was cooled down to 50 °C and purged using an H2 atmosphere to achieve adsorption equilibrium. Finally, the temperature is incrementally raised from 50 to 500 °C (10 °C/min) to monitor the desorption of hydrogen under the He atmosphere (40 mL/min). 2.4 Catalytic evaluations The hydrodeoxygenation reaction of vanillin was conducted in a 50 mL Schlenk glass tube equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a standard catalytic process, vanillin (0.5 mmol, 76 mg), catalyst (5 mg), and 5 mL of water were added into the reactor. The reactor was sealed and purged with H2 several times to replace the air inside the reactor, and pressurized with H2 to 1 atm, then heated to the pre-determined reaction temperature with stirring at 500 r/min. After a specific reaction duration, the rapid cooling of the reactor was performed. The reaction mixture including the products and used catalyst was separated by centrifugation. Product identification was conducted using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Agilent 5975 C/7890A) equipped with a HP-5MS column. Reactant conversion and product selectivity were determined utilizing an internal standard method on a gas chromatograph (GC 9720Plus, ZHE JIANG FULI ANALYTICAL INSTRUMENTS INC) equipped with a SE-54 capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The corresponding standard curves and calibration factors of various reactant and product were shown in Fig. S1 in the supporting information. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The VASP code was utilized to conduct DFT calculations in this study [41]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional, a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [42], was employed to handle the exchange-correlation. Additionally, the projector-augmented-wave (PAW) pseudopotential was utilized with a kinetic energy cut-off of 500 eV to describe the expansion of the electronic eigenfunctions [43]. A vacuum thickness of 25 Å was set to reduce interlayer interactions. The Brillouin-zone integration was sampled using a Γ-centered 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid. All atomic positions were fully relaxed until the energy and force reached a tolerance of 1 × 10–6 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. Furthermore, the dispersion-corrected DFT-D method was incorporated to account for long-range interactions [44]. In this work, two network graphene models with a 6 × 6 supercell were constructed, and the corresponding unit cell parameters were a = b = 14.80370 Å, α = β = 90°, and γ = 120°. The pyridinic N and graphitic N atoms were doped in models 1 and 2, respectively. As for the supported Pd nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped carbon, a Pd cluster model consisting of 30 Pd atoms was adopted. The adsorption energy of E ads was calculated using Eq. (1) as follows: (1) E ads = E X+sur – E sur – E X E x+sur is the total energy of the adsorption complex including the nitrogen-doped carbon-supported Pd clusters model and adsorbed species, E sur is the total energy of the nitrogen-doped carbon-supported Pd clusters model surface, and E x is the energy of the free adsorbates. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the Pd@NHCS catalysts The synthetic procedure towards Pd@NHCS catalysts is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . Firstly, SiO2 nanospheres were fabricated using the Stöber method via the hydrolysis and condensation of TEOS. Subsequently, the carbon precursor of dopamine (DA) polymerized with the assistance of the SiO2 template in Tris solution. Along with the generation of polydopamine (PDA), K2PdCl4 was introduced and resulted in the formation of the PdCl4 2–-PDA@SiO2 composite due to the chelating ability of PDA to metal species. After the composite calcination at 600–800 °C and following NaOH etching, a series of N-doped hollow carbon spheres encapsulated with Pd catalysts Pd@NHCS-X (X = 600–800) were afforded. The phase composition and crystal properties of various Pd@NHCS-X (X: 600–800) catalysts were investigated by XRD. As shown in Fig. 2(a) , all catalysts exhibited the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 40.2°, 46.7°, 68.2°, and 82.3°, which were attributed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of face-centered cubic (fcc) palladium (JCPDS No. 15-0806) [45,46], respectively. Moreover, the intensities of these diffraction peaks gradually enhanced with increasing the calcination temperature, indicating the crystal growth of the Pd nanoparticle. Additionally, a weak broad diffraction peak at around 21.6° was observed for all catalysts, corresponding to the (002) lattice planes of graphitic carbon with the lattice distortion and grain boundary effects. These above characteristic diffraction peaks also existed in the XRD patterns of Pd@NHCS-600-Y (Y = 0.6–6.3) catalysts with different Pd metal loadings (Fig. S1). Furthermore, as the Pd loading was elevated, the diffraction peaks of Pd became more distinct, suggesting an enhancement in the crystallinity of Pd NPs. The FTIR spectra of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(b). The broad peak located at 3453 cm–1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the O–H group. The peak intensity of the O–H group for Pd@NHCS-X catalyst gradually decreased with the increase of calcination temperature, which was ascribed to the increased decomposition degree and was consistent with the following Raman and TG results. These peaks at 2922 and 2840 cm–1 were assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the –CH2– group [47], respectively. The characteristic adsorption peaks of C=C, C–C, and C–O stretching vibrations were observed at 1612, 1458, and 1120 cm–1, respectively. Three peaks at 681, 779, and 856 cm–1 corresponded to the C–H out-of-plane bending vibration [48]. Apart from the oxygen-containing functional groups, abundant nitrogen-containing functional groups also existed on the surface of Pd@NHCS catalysts. The two peaks at 1360 and 623 cm–1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of the C–N bond and the out-of-plane bending vibration of the N–H bond [49], respectively. The presence of nitrogen-containing groups facilitated the encapsulation of Pd active sites and the modulation of their electronic properties. Moreover, the characteristic vibration of the Pd–N bond was observed at 547 cm–1 [50], which further confirmed the strong interaction between Pd active centers and the nitrogen species of NHCS support. Additionally, these different nitrogen- and oxygen-containing groups endowed the Pd@NHCS catalysts with favorable hydrophilic properties and promoted the uniform dispersion of catalysts in the aqueous phase HDO reaction. Raman spectra of Pd@NHCS-X (X = 600–800) catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(c). Two prominent peaks at approximately 1332 and 1583 cm–1 were ascribed to the D band and the G band, which stemmed from the disordered carbon and the in-plane stretching vibration of sp 2 hybridized graphitic carbon [51], respectively. The intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (I D/I G) reflects the graphitization degree and the disorder level of the N-doped hollow carbon sphere. The I D/I G ratio gradually increased from 0.834 to 0.978 with the increase of calcination temperature from 600 to 800 °C. It indicated that a higher carbonization temperature could enhance the defect density of NHCS supports, which was caused by the decomposition of more functional groups during the carbonization process. TG analysis was used to determine the thermal decomposition process of the PdCl4 2–-PDA@SiO2 precursor under the inert atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 2(d), the first stage of weight loss below 192 °C indicated the removal of surface water. From 192 to 584 °C, the weight loss was ascribed to the decomposition of PDA and the removal of water caused by the polycondensation of the Si–OH groups [52,53]. Moreover, the corresponding DTG curve revealed that the high decomposition rate occurred at the temperatures of 362 and 550 °C during the second stage of weight loss, which provided a basis for regulating the calcination temperature of Pd@NHCS catalysts. The specific surface areas and pore structure characteristics of the synthesized Pd@NHCS-X (X = 600–800) catalysts were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. As shown in Fig. 2(e), all the Pd@NHCS catalysts showed a similar adsorption-desorption isotherm with a sharp steep N2 uptake at the low relative pressure (P/P 0) and a distinct hysteresis loop, indicating the coexistence of micropore and mesopore structures. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas of catalysts are shown in Table 1 . The Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented the largest specific surface area of 275.17 m2/g, which was beneficial for the exposure of catalytic active centers and enhanced the mass transfer efficiency for HDO reaction. Moreover, the corresponding pore size distribution profiles (Fig. 2(f)) calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method revealed the Pd@NHCS catalysts possessed micropores, mesopores, and macropores, further confirming the formation of hierarchical porous structure. Such hierarchical pores were attributed to the diffusion and growth of Pd nanoparticles and the carbonization of PDA precursor, as well as the release of gas volatiles during the pyrolysis process. Therefore, a proper calcination temperature could effectively regulate the textural properties and generate the large specific surface area and abundant porous structure, which made the reactant and intermediate molecules more easily accessible to the surface active sites of Pd@NHCS catalysts and improved the catalytic activity for subsequent vanillin HDO reaction. The morphology and microstructure of different samples were characterized by SEM and TEM techniques. As shown in Fig. S3(a), the synthesized SiO2 nanospheres presented the regular spherical morphology with the smooth surface and uniform particle size of about 420 nm. After the polymerization and calcination treatment, the surface of SiO2 nanosphere template became rough (Fig. S3(b)), indicating the successful formation of Pd@NCS@SiO2-600 core-shell structure. As expected, the prepared Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst perfectly inherited the original structure of Pd@NCS@SiO2-600 precursor (Fig. 3(a) ), whereas the sphere sizes were slightly reduced and some tiny nanoparticles were homogeneously distributed on their surfaces. The unique hollow structure of Pd@NHCS-600 could be recognized clearly from some flattened particles. TEM further demonstrated the successful formation of well-defined hollow sphere morphology for the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst (Fig. 3(b)), which possessed an average diameter of 470 nm and a wall thickness about 17 nm. Notably, a large number of Pd NPs with a mean size of 6.34 nm were semi-embedded in the exterior N-doped hollow carbon shell as revealed from the TEM and STEM images (Fig. S4). The microstructure of Pd NPs was further revealed by HRTEM (Figs. 3(c), S5–S9). The characteristic interlayer spacing of 0.224 nm corresponded to the (111) lattice plane of metallic Pd [54]. In addition, several Pd NPs were partially encapsulated by ultrathin carbon layers with an interlayer spacing of 0.334 nm ascribed to the (002) lattice plane [55]. The HAADF-STEM (Fig. 3(d)) and corresponding energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping revealed the C, N, Pd, and O elements (Figs. 3(e)–(i)) were homogeneously distributed in the hollow carbon framework over the whole Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst. Moreover, the morphology and microstructure of Pd@NHCS-700, Pd@NHCS-800, and Pd@NHCS-600-Y (Y = 0.6–6.3) were investigated by TEM (Figs. S10 and S11), which exhibited the similar morphologies and hollow structures to those of Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst. However, the diameter and shell thickness of the hollow carbon sphere gradually became smaller due to the structural shrinkage with increasing the calcination temperature from 600 to 800 °C (Fig. S10). The average diameters of Pd NPs for Pd@NHCS-700 and Pd@NHCS-800 were 8.37 and 8.77 nm, respectively, as confirmed by the corresponding particle size distribution histograms (Fig. S10). As for the Pd@NHCS-600-Y (Y = 0.6–5.7) catalysts with different metal loadings, there was a slight increase in the average diameter of Pd NPs as increasing the Pd loading (Fig. S11). Besides, the particle sizes of Pd NPs for various catalysts were determined using Scherrer equation based on the half-height peak widths of XRD patterns (Figs. 2(a) and S2). The variation tendency of particle size for Pd NPs with the calcination temperature and the Pd loading was consistent with above TEM results (Table S1). 3.2 Catalytic HDO performance of various catalysts The catalytic performance of the N-doped hollow carbon sphere encapsulated with Pd catalysts and other transition metal catalysts including Ru, Pt, Co, Ni, and Cu were evaluated in the selective aqueous phase hydrodeoxygenation of vanillin under the reaction conditions of 120 °C and 0.1 MPa H2 for 6 h. As depicted in Table 2 , the blank experiment without a catalyst failed to induce the vanillin HDO reaction (entry 1). When utilizing the single N-doped hollow carbon sphere of NHCS-600 as the catalyst, there was nearly no vanillin conversion obtained (entry 2), suggesting the sole carbon support was insufficient to drive the vanillin HDO reaction. In sharp contrast to the NHCS-600 support, it can be clearly seen that the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst exhibited the highest 100% vanillin conversion with a 100% selectivity towards 2-methoxy-4- methylphenol among all tested samples (entry 3). Subsequently, the catalytic HDO reactions of Pd@NHCS-700 and Pd@NHCS-800 catalysts were investigated to study the effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performance. A 95% vanillin conversion was obtained over the Pd@NHCS-700 catalyst which afforded a 90% MMP selectivity. Meanwhile, a 10% selectivity of vanillyl alcohol (VA) was detected (entry 4). As increasing the calcination temperature, the catalytic HDO activity of the Pd@NHCS-800 catalyst obviously declined, which only showed a low 52% vanillin conversion (entry 5). It can be inferred that the suitable calcination temperature of Pd@NHCS catalysts substantially contributed to enhancing the catalytic HDO efficiency and MMP selectivity. To highlight the catalytic advantage of Pd@NHCS-600 for vanillin HDO, the catalytic performance of other noble metal catalysts such as the Ru@NHCS-600 and Pt@NHCS-600, were also evaluated under the same reaction conditions (entries 6, 7). As expected, the inferior catalytic activity and MMP selectivity were afforded. Especially for the Pt@NHCS-600 catalyst, the reaction product was merely VA (entry 6). Moreover, the N-doped hollow carbon sphere encapsulated with non-noble metal catalysts such as Co/Ni/Cu@NHCS-600 presented poor catalytic activity for vanillin HDO, where almost no conversion of vanillin was observed over these catalysts (entries 8–10). These results indicated the nature of catalytic active metal centers embedded in the NHCS support played a crucial role in vanillin HDO, and the Pd active centers performed particularly outstanding. In order to demonstrate the promoted role of N-doping on the catalytic HDO performance, the Pd@HCS-600 catalyst without N-doping was evaluated, which presented a low vanillin conversion of 66% with 74% selectivity towards MMP (entry 11). Notably, the Pd@NC-600 catalyst exhibited the substantially declined catalytic activity and MMP selectivity as compared with the Pd@NHCS-600 (entry 12). Additionally, the Pd@NCS@SiO2-600 catalyst with the presence of silica was fabricated and evaluated for vanillin HDO under the same reaction condition (entry 13). It only afforded a 56% selectivity of target MMP with 57% conversion of vanillin. The above experimental results and the discussions fully demonstrated the Pd@NHCS-600 nanoreactor with hollow configuration was more conducive to the HDO of vanillin to produce target MMP. Encouraged by the excellent catalytic performance of Pd@NHCS-600 for vanillin HDO reaction, we further investigated the effect of Pd metal loading of Pd@NHCS-600-Y on catalytic activity and selectivity (Table S2). As for the Pd@NHCS-600-0.6 catalyst with a 0.6 wt% Pd loading, only a low 20% vanillin conversion with the 78% selectivity toward MMP was obtained. With the increment of Pd loading from 0.6 to 6.3 wt%, the vanillin conversion presented a remarkable increase trend. Meanwhile, the selectivity of target MMP gradually enhanced from 78% to 100%. Moreover, in order to study the intrinsic catalytic activity of various Pd@NHCS-600-Y catalysts for vanillin HDO, the turnover frequency (TOF) values of Pd@NHCS-600-Y (Y = 0.6–6.3) catalysts were calculated according to equations (4–6) in the supporting information. As shown in Table S3, the TOF values of Pd@NHCS-600-Y catalysts increased gradually from 320.76 to 337.77 h–1 with the Pd loading increased from 0.6 wt% to 6.3 wt%. The optimal Pd@NHCS-600 with a 6.3 wt% Pd loading exhibited the highest TOF value of 337.77 h–1. Additionally, a largest initial reaction rate of 30.54 mmol/(g·h) was achieved for the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst. This result further demonstrated the crucial role of Pd active centers in vanillin HDO reaction. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions and solvent effects In order to study the reaction pathway of aqueous phase HDO of vanillin to MMP, the effects of various reaction parameters including the reaction temperature, catalyst dosage and reaction time, on the catalytic activity and selectivity of Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst were conducted. As shown in Fig. 4(a) , the reaction temperature presented a noticeable impact on the catalytic selectivity for vanillin HDO. As increasing the reaction temperature from 80 to 120 °C, the conversion of vanillin enhanced gradually from 96% to 100%, while the selectivity of MMP increased steadily from 45% to 100%, It suggested that high temperatures could promote the HDO reaction of vanillin. Moreover, the catalyst dosage played an equally important role in the HDO reaction. With an extremely low catalyst dosage of 2 mg, only a 75% conversion of vanillin with the 84.5% selectivity of MMP was obtained (Fig. 4(b)). Increasing appropriately the amount of catalyst achieved satisfactory vanillin conversion and product selectivity. A complete 100% conversion of vanillin with 100% selectivity toward MMP was afforded at 120 °C with only 5 mg catalyst dosage. As depicted in Fig. 4(c), the time course profile was established to investigate the reaction process of vanillin aqueous phase HDO over Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst under the optimized conditions of 120 °C and 0.1 MPa H2. In the first 20 min of the reaction, the conversion of vanillin was extremely low, and only a VA with 100% selectivity was detected. With the extension of reaction time, the conversion of vanillin continued to increase, leading to a gradual shift in the product distribution towards MMP as the predominant outcome. After six hours, the selectivity of MMP increased to the highest 100% level under the complete vanillin conversion. In contrast, the selectivity of VA presented a gradually decreasing trend. It indicated that the reaction pathway for vanillin HDO to produce MMP was composed of two consecutive steps. The first step involved the selective hydrogenation of vanillin to generate VA intermediate by converting the –C=O group into the –CH2OH group. Then the second step involved the selective hydrogenolysis of the –C–O bond in VA to produce the target MMP. Moreover, as deduced from the time course profile, the second step of VA hydrogenolysis to MMP should be the rate-determining step in the whole vanillin HDO tandem reaction. The reusability and stability of the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst for the aqueous phase HDO of vanillin were examined (Figs. 4(d) and S12(a)). After five cycles, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst still maintained the outstanding catalytic efficiency for the vanillin HDO in both cases of the complete and moderate conversions. There was no obvious decline in both the conversion of vanillin and the selectivity of MMP in the five catalytic runs. Moreover, the structure properties of the reused Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst were characterized by XRD, TEM and ICP-AES. The characteristic diffraction peaks of Pd phase and carbon support were almost identical to those of the fresh catalyst as confirmed by XRD patterns (Fig. S12(b)). The reused Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst fairly maintained the morphology and structure characters of the fresh one, which did not exhibit the severe agglomeration of the Pd NP as revealed from the TEM and the corresponding particle size distribution histogram (Figs. S12(c) and (d)). In addition, ICP-AES was used to evaluate the Pd loading after five recycling cycles. There was no obviously detectable Pd leaching in the used Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst (Table S4). The excellent stability of the as-synthesized Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst was mainly attributed to the unique confined structure with hierarchical pores and the presence of abundant nitrogen species in carbon support, which facilitated the homogeneous dispersion and stabilization of Pd NPs. The Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst with satisfactory stability could greatly promote the practical industrial application for biomass conversion. Solvents are widely considered to play a crucial role in determining the rate and product selectivity of heterogeneous reactions [56–58]. In order to evaluate the effects of solvent on catalytic HDO of vanillin, a series of solvents with different properties were investigated over the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst under the reaction conditions of 120 °C and 0.1 MPa H2 for 6 h. As shown in Table S5, the solvent exhibited a significant effect on the catalytic efficiency and selectivity of the vanillin HDO reaction. It was found that the strongly polar solvent of water provided substantially superior catalytic performance as compared with other solvents. Notably, when using different organic solvents including various alcohols, 1,4-dioxane, and toluene as the reaction medium of vanillin HDO, an evident decrease in the catalytic activity was observed (entries 2–7) and the highest conversion of vanillin only reached 50% with the 19% MMP selectivity in ethanol (entry 3). In the other organic solvents (entries 4–7), a lower catalytic conversion within the range of 33%–45% was obtained, and the main reaction product was VA instead of the target MMP. It further indicated that water is the highly desirable green solvent for the vanillin HDO under the catalysis of Pd@NHCS-600. Moreover, in the case of methanol and ethanol as the solvent, the byproducts of methyl vanillyl ether and vanillyl ethyl ether with a selectivity of 55% and 23% were generated, which resulted from the etherification of vanillyl alcohol intermediate with methanol and ethanol molecules, respectively (entries 2–3). Such a high selectivity towards the byproducts of ethers suggested the hydrogenolysis of VA to MMP was significantly inhibited within the solvent of methanol/ethanol. This result might be attributed to the strong adsorption ability of methanol and ethanol molecules on the surface of Pd catalyst [59–62], which easily led to the etherification of vanillyl alcohol with the solvent molecules and was not conducive to the second step of VA hydrogenolysis. To further investigate the promoted effect of water solvent on the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyzed vanillin HDO reaction. A series of mixed solvents consisting of different proportions of water and ethanol were used as the reaction medium for vanillin HDO (Table S6). It is noteworthy that the increase of water proportion in the mixed solvents could not only enhance the conversion of vanillin, but also significantly improve the selectivity of MMP product with the catalysis of Pd@NHCS-600. When a 50% proportion of water was added to the mixed solvent, the selectivity of MMP increased obviously from 19% to 78% and the corresponding selectivity of vanillyl ethyl ether decreased from 23% to 9%. If further increasing the proportion of water in the mixed solvent, the MMP selectivity continued to increase until the highest 100% level and the selectivity of ether byproduct simultaneously presented an opposite trend. The above results suggested that the introduction of water could suppress the etherification reaction between vanillyl alcohol and ethanol. Besides, the substantial enhancement of vanillin conversion in pure water indicated that the water molecule could accelerate the catalytic conversion of vanillin during the HDO reaction. Based on this result, the adsorption behaviors of the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst for both vanillin and vanillyl alcohol in water and ethanol were systematically investigated, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5(a) and Fig. S13, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst displayed stronger adsorption capabilities for both vanillin and vanillyl alcohol in the solvent of water. Moreover, the adsorption profile demonstrated the promoted role of water in the adsorption of vanillin. After 6 h of adsorption examination in water, the concentration of vanillin declined by 39.2%, which was obviously larger than that of ethanol with 24.2% (Fig. 5(b)). Interestingly, the water solvent promoted the preferential adsorption of vanillyl alcohol on the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst surface could also be confirmed. A more noticeable change of the vanillyl alcohol concentration with 45.9% was obtained in water as compared with the low change of 17% in ethanol (Fig. 5(c)). These results further confirmed the above solvent effect as illustrated in Tables S5 and S6. Within the green solvent of water, the –C=O group of vanillin could readily adsorb on the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst, which facilitated the selective hydrogenation of vanillin to produce VA. More importantly, the efficient adsorption and cleavage of the –C–O bond of the VA intermediate also proceeded successively, thus affording a high yield of MMP over the optimal Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst. 3.4 Relationship of structure-performance for Pd@NHCS catalysts As mentioned above, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance in the aqueous phase HDO of vanillin to produce MMP, which was closely related to the specific surface microenvironment of catalysts. To further study the underlying microenvironment effects in our catalytic system, the corresponding relationship of structure-performance was investigated. In concrete, the catalytic intrinsic kinetic evaluation and systematic structure and property characterizations were conducted through wettability testing, H2-TPD, UV-vis, and XPS measurements. Firstly, the TOF values of Pd@NHCS-X (X: 600–800) catalysts were investigated using equations (4–6) (in supporting information) by controlling the vanillin conversion below 10%. The calculation results indicated the TOF values of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts gradually decreased with the calcination temperature increasing from 600 to 800 °C. The Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented the largest TOF value of 337.77 h–1, which was nearly 3 times larger than that of the Pd@NHCS-800 catalyst (81.83 h–1). The initial reaction rates of various Pd@NHCS-X catalysts also presented a similar increasing trend (Table S3). Figs. 6(a) –(c) showed the linear correlations between the Napierian logarithm of vanillin conversion and reaction time at temperatures ranging from 80 to 100 °C, indicating the first-order reaction kinetic characteristic of the vanillin HDO process. The corresponding apparent activation energies of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts for vanillin HDO reaction were calculated based on the experimentally measured Arrhenius plots (Figs. 6(d)–(f)). The results showed that the apparent activation energies of the Pd@NHCS-600, Pd@NHCS-700, and Pd@NHCS-800 catalysts were 18.63, 25.03, and 46.31 kJ/mol, respectively. Such low apparent activation energies further indicated the superior catalytic HDO performance of Pd@NHCS catalysts. Therefore, the mild reaction conditions, environmentally friendly reaction medium, and rapid reaction kinetics compared with the previously reported metal catalysts (Table S7), will significantly promote the practical application of Pd@NHCS catalyst for vanillin HDO reaction. Owing to the Pd@NHCS catalyzed vanillin HDO is a typical heterogeneous catalysis process, it generally involves the molecular adsorption and desorption as well as the molecular transfer of reactant and product on the surface of catalysts. The appropriate surface wettability may improve the adsorption/desorption and transfer of reactant, intermediate, and product on catalyst, leading to the enhancement of catalytic activity and selectivity. As shown in Figs. 7(a)–(c) , the surface wettability of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts were characterized by measuring the water contact angles. According to the dynamic wetting process of water droplets on the catalyst surface, it can be clearly seen that all the Pd@NHCS-X catalysts presented proper hydrophilicity as inferred from the change of contact angles. Especially for the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst, the water droplet could completely wet the catalyst surface in just 3.2 s. Pd@NHCS-700 and Pd@NHCS-800 catalysts exhibited a similar wetting process of water droplets, but took a longer wetting time of 4.1 and 5.2 s, respectively. The excellent hydrophilicity was attributed to the existence of abundant nitrogen- and oxygen-containing groups on the catalyst surface as revealed by the above FTIR spectra (Fig. 2(b)). As a comparison, the Pd@HCS-600 catalyst present typical hydrophobicity with a water contact angle of 145° (Fig. S14). This result further indicated that the N doping could regulate the surface wettability of NHCS support and endow the supported metal catalysts with proper hydrophilicity. In order to demonstrate the hydrophilicity nature of the obtained catalysts, the representative Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst was dispersed in both the water and the biphasic solution composed of ethyl acetate and water (Fig. 7(d)), respectively. As expected, the sustainedly homogeneous dispersion of the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst in water could be observed within 6 hours. More interestingly, the catalyst was only well-dispersed in the bottom layer of water in the case of a biphasic solution, further suggesting the outstanding hydrophilicity of the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst. It has been confirmed that the wettability of the catalyst surface usually affects the diffusion rate of the reactant or product [63]. The hydrophilic Pd@NHCS catalysts can be well-dispersed in water, which makes both the vanillin reactant and VA intermediate more easily accessible to the active sites of the catalyst surface during the aqueous phase HDO reaction. Moreover, the aforementioned solvent effect has pointed out the green solvent of water could promote the adsorption of vanillin and VA intermediate on the catalyst surface (Fig. 5). In addition, the hydrophilic Pd@NHCS may facilitate the desorption of MMP product from the catalyst surface due to the relative hydrophobic character of MMP. Once the MMP with hydrophobicity was generated, it could leave the catalyst surface quickly and expose more active sites for the selective adsorption of hydrophilic vanillin reactant and VA intermediate, thus accelerating the tandem HDO reaction process. The fine hydrophilic performance ensures that the catalyst can be uniformly dispersed in water, which provides a prerequisite for the adsorptions of H2 and vanillin reactants. H2-TPD and UV-vis spectra were used to study the adsorption abilities of H2 and vanillin molecules on the surface of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts. As displayed in the H2-TPD profiles (Fig. 7(e)), all Pd@NHCS catalysts exhibited two desorption peaks in the temperature ranges of 50–140 and 290–430 °C, which were ascribed to the weakly chemisorbed hydrogen and the strongly chemisorbed hydrogen, respectively. Moreover, the hydrogen adsorption capabilities of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts were evaluated according to the integrated areas of the corresponding H2-TPD profiles. Notably, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst exhibited the largest adsorbed hydrogen amount of 107.5 μmol/g (Table 1), which was substantially superior to the Pd@NHCS-700 (70.0 μmol/g) and Pd@NHCS-800 (97.5 μmol/g) catalysts. It suggested that the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented the strongest catalytic capability for the dissociation and activation of H2 molecules due to the strong interaction between H2 molecules and the catalyst surface, thus producing abundant active hydrogen species and improving the tandem hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reaction process of vanillin. This result was also consistent with the fastest catalytic reaction kinetic of Pd@NHCS-600, which has the smallest activation energy and the largest TOF for vanillin HDO. In addition to H2 molecules, the adsorption behavior of vanillin on the Pd@NHCS-X catalysts was investigated using UV-vis spectra to gain more insights into their different catalytic performances during the vanillin HDO. As shown in Fig. 7(f), the adsorption capability of vanillin on the catalysts presented the trend of Pd@NHCS-600 > Pd@NHCS-700 > Pd@NHCS-800 > NHCS-600. This trend was also consistent with their catalytic performances as displayed in Table 2 and Fig. 6. The strong adsorption capability for vanillin on the surface of Pd@NHCS-600 confirmed the close interaction between vanillin and the catalytic active sites, which was beneficial for the surface activation of vanillin and the following hydrodeoxygenation reaction. The surface electron property of active metal centers usually plays crucial roles in the adsorption and activation of reactants and intermediates during the HDO reaction. XPS analysis was used to elucidate the surface chemical states and the electronic metal-support interaction of N-doped hollow carbon spheres encapsulated with Pd catalysts. As shown in Fig. S15(a), the survey scan manifested the existence of C, N, O, and Pd elements in the Pd@NHCS-X catalysts. The high-resolution C 1s spectra of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts could be deconvoluted into four peaks centered at 284.6, 285.3, 286.4, and 288.7 eV, corresponding to the C–C/C=C, C–N, C–O, and C=O species (Fig. S15(b)), respectively. The presence of C-N peaks at 285. 3 eV for all catalysts confirmed the successful doping of N atoms into the hollow carbon framework, which was also consistent with the FTIR results (Fig. 2(b)). As for the N-doped porous carbon-supported metal catalysts, the introduction of N species could induce the electronic metal-support interaction and regulate the surface electron property of active metal centers. To confirm this, we attempted to investigate the metal-support interaction between Pd and N by altering the nitrogen contents of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts. In our catalytic system, the corresponding nitrogen contents of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts could be regulated by the calcination temperature. As shown in Table 1, the nitrogen contents of Pd@NHCS catalysts diminished from 2.21% to 1.04% with the increase of calcination temperature from 600 to 800 °C. The high-resolution N 1s spectra of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts and the corresponding NHCS-X supports were analyzed, and could be divided into four peaks: pyridinic N (398.3 eV), pyrrolic N (400.2 eV), graphitic N (401.2 eV), and N-oxide (402.8 eV) (Fig. 8(a) ). Notably, the pyridinic N peak of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts obviously shifted to a higher binding energy value as compared to their corresponding pure NHCS supports, indicating the presence of electron transfer from N species to Pd NPs which enhanced the surface electron density of Pd NPs. For the Pd 3d spectra of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts (Fig. 8(b)), the characteristic peaks at 335.23 and 340.41 eV were assigned to Pd0 3d 5/2 and Pd0 3d 3/2, while the peaks at 336.53 and 342.28 eV were ascribed to Pd2+ 3d 5/2 and Pd2+ 3d 3/2, respectively [45]. Moreover, the proportions of four nitrogen species in Pd@NHCS-X catalysts were deconvoluted and displayed in Fig. 8(c). The content of pyrrolic N only accounted for 4.0%–10.5%, which was much less than that of pyridinic N (24.8%–37.1%) and graphitic N (42.3%–60.3%). Besides, the weaker electronegativity of pyrrolic N compared with the pyridinic N generally leads to a weak interaction with Pd. Therefore, we mainly investigated the most abundant pyridinic N and graphitic N in the following discussion. These two types of N configurations and the corresponding electronic constructions of adjacent carbon atoms in the N-doping hollow carbon sphere supports are schematically elucidated in Fig. 8(d). To deeply study the electronic metal-support interaction between active Pd sites and the surface nitrogen species, the binding energies of pyridinic N and graphitic N before and after loading Pd NPs on NHCS supports were analyzed. As shown in Fig. 9(a) , regardless of the nitrogen species, the introduction of Pd increased their binding energies to different degrees. Notably, the binding energy of pyridinic N species of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts was obviously higher than that of their corresponding NHCS supports, while the graphitic N showed almost no shift alteration in the binding energy, indicating the strong electronic interaction between pyridinic N and Pd sites enhanced their surface electron density. Fig. 9(b) also demonstrated the binding energy of pyridinic N significantly increased by 0.08–0.17 eV after Pd loading, which was much higher than that of graphitic N with a low deviation value of 0.02 eV. More importantly, the greater the change in the binding energy of pyridinic N, the lower the binding energy of Pd0 species. These results clearly confirmed that the pyridinic N and graphitic N could provide electrons to Pd NPs and lead to the formation of electron-rich active Pd sites. Moreover, the electron transfer preferred to occur between Pd and pyridinic N configuration in the NHCS support. The amount of electron transfer could control the surface electronic property of active Pd sites of Pd@NHCS catalysts and regulate their catalytic performance for vanillin HDO. Particularly, the most significant change of pyridinic N binding energy was observed for the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst, which possessed the lowest binding energy of Pd0 species and showed the optimal catalytic activity and selectivity among the three catalysts. In addition to the change of binding energy, the contents of pyridinic N and graphitic N configurations before and after Pd loading presented obvious variations, which could also be used to elucidate the priority of electronic interaction between Pd and pyridinic N and graphitic N. The pyrolysis treatment effectively adjusted the ratio of pyridinic N and graphitic N (N P/N G). As displayed in Fig. 9(c), the N P/N G ratio of NHCS supports declined from 1.03 to 0.44 with the calcination temperature increased from 600 to 800 °C. Notably, the N P/N Gratios of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts exhibited a similar decrease trend, but were obviously lower than the corresponding NHCS-X supports. This result also suggested the substantial electronic interaction between Pd and pyridinic N, thus facilitating the nucleation of electron-rich active Pd sites around the pyridinic N species. This result was also consistent with the corresponding energy offsets of pyridinic N and graphitic N species of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts. However, it could be clearly seen that the extent of the decrease in the N P/N G ratio of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts gradually declined with the increase in calcination temperature. As for the Pd@NHCS-800 catalyst, the N P/N G ratio showed almost no change compared with the NHCS-800 support before Pd loading. It was attributed to the reduction of total nitrogen species, leading to the saturation of nearly all nitrogen sites by Pd NPs. To validate the aforementioned conclusion, Fig. 9(d), Fig. S16, and Fig. S17 illustrated the effects of Pd content on the electronic metal-support interaction. It should be noted that the binding energy of pyridinic N gradually rose over the Pd@NHCS-600-Y catalysts as increasing the Pd content, suggesting the presence of electron transfer from pyridinic N to Pd NPs. Indeed, the binding energy of Pd0 species changed with a trend opposite to that of pyridinic N, which demonstrated more electrons transferred from pyridinic N to Pd NPs with the increase of Pd content. The lowest binding energy of Pd0 was obtained over the optimized Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst with a high Pd loading of 6.3 wt%. Meanwhile, there was no obvious change in the binding energy of graphitic N species, further indicating the weak interaction between Pd and graphitic N species. This result further confirmed the prevalence of pyridinic N-dominated electron transfer to active Pd sites in the Pd@NHCS catalyst system, thereby completely consistent with the above conclusions (Figs. 9(a)–(c)). The strong electron transfer between pyridinic N and Pd NPs modified the surface electronic property of active Pd sites and produced the surface electron-rich Pd centers, which significantly promoted the adsorption and activation of vanillin and H2 molecules and improved the catalytic HDO performance. As shown in Fig. 9(e), the correlations between TOF values and the contents of various Pd species of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts were established. The TOF values of Pd@NHCS-X catalysts almost declined linearly with the content of Pd0 species decreasing from 72.1% to 55.1%. The optimal Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst with the highest Pd0 content of 72.1% owned the largest TOF value with 337.77 h–1. It has been proven that the high content of Pd0 active sites could substantially promote the adsorption and activation of H2 and vanillin molecules, and enhance the catalytic HDO activity, which was also in good agreement with the H2-TPD and UV-vis results (Figs. 7 (e) and (f)). Moreover, the relationships between TOF values and various N species were analyzed as illustrated in Fig. 9(f). It should be noted that the type and content of surface nitrogen species could be controlled by the calcination temperature of catalysts, which effectively regulated the surface microenvironment of Pd@NHCS catalyst and endowed the catalyst with suitable hydrophilicity and surface electron property through electronic metal-support interaction. Notably, the content of pyridinic N species declined from 38.8% to 24.8% with the increase of calcination temperature from 600 to 800 °C. Accordingly, the strength of EMSI between pyridinic N and Pd gradually weakened. As expected, the corresponding TOF values substantially diminished with the decrease of the pyridinic N content within the Pd@NHCS-X catalysts. These results confirmed that the pyridinic N-dominated the electronic property modulation of active Pd sites could effectively accelerate the catalytic HDO transformation of vanillin over the Pd@NHCS catalysts. 3.5 Catalytic reaction mechanism of vanillin hydrodeoxygenation During the vanillin hydrodeoxygenation reaction of Pd@NHCS catalyzed, the electronic property of active Pd sites played a determined role in the strength of their interactions with reactant molecules. Based on the above analysis of the structure-performance relationship, DFT calculations were used to gain a deep insight into the electronic metal-support interaction between Pd and N-doped carbon support for the N-doped hollow carbon spheres encapsulated with Pd catalysts. By analyzing the charge density differences of Pd sites interacting with the graphitic N and pyridinic N-doped carbon support, it was found that both two N species could cause electrons transfer to Pd sites (Figs. 10 (a) and (c) ), suggesting the introduction of N species in NHCS support modified the electronic property of active Pd centers. Bader charge analysis indicated the interfacial charge transfer from graphitic N and pyridinic N-doped carbon supports to Pd sites were 1.64 and 1.85 e (Figs. 10 (a) and (c)), respectively. Moreover, the 2D charge density difference maps demonstrated the pyridinic N species induced more electrons transfer from support to active Pd centers (Figs. 10 (b) and (d)). It also suggested the pyridinic N species could exert the dominant role of electron donors to enhance the electron density of Pd sites, thus leading to the formation of electron-rich active Pd centers. This result was entirely consistent with the above XPS analysis (Figs. 9(a)–(c)). The d-band center (ε d) of Pd metal in these two models was also calculated, which was closely related to the intrinsic catalytic activity of supported Pd catalysts. Generally, a higher εd causes the reduction in antibonding orbital filling of metal centers and promotes the chemical bonding between active metal centers and adsorbate [26,64]. Based on the density of states (DOS) analysis, it was found that the energy overlap of d-orbital electrons of Pd and the p-orbital electrons of N or C around the Fermi level was responsible for the interaction between N-doped carbon support and Pd active sites. Moreover, the ε d of Pd anchored on the graphitic N and pyridinic N-doped carbon supports was –1.12 and –0.73 eV (Fig. 10(e)), respectively. The more positively shifted ε d toward the Fermi level demonstrated the enhancement of vanillin adsorption on the surface of pyridinic N-doped carbon-supported Pd catalyst, which has also been established from the adsorption energies (ΔE ads) of the vanillin on these two catalysts. The adsorption energies of vanillin on the Pd anchored on the graphitic N and pyridinic N-doped carbon were –2.67 and –3.12 eV (Fig. 10(f)), respectively, suggesting the advantage of pyridinic N-dominated electronic property modulation. Furthermore, the negatively shifted ΔE ads confirmed that the pyridinic N coordinated Pd could promote vanillin adsorption on the catalyst surface and enhance its hydrodeoxygenation. In addition, the clearly elongated -C=O bond of the aldehyde group in vanillin adsorbed on the pyridinic N-doped carbon-based catalyst as compared with those of graphitic N demonstrated the significantly improved activation of vanillin by the pyridinic N coordinated Pd (Scheme S1), which facilitated the efficient aqueous phase hydrodeoxygenation of vanillin to produce MMP under mild reaction conditions. Based on the above structure-performance relationship studies and DFT calculations, the catalytic reaction mechanism of vanillin HDO over the Pd@NHCS catalyst was proposed (Fig. 11 ). The fine hydrophilicity and hierarchical porous structure endow the catalyst with highly uniform dispersion in water, making the reactants easily accessible to the catalytical active sites and triggering the HDO of vanillin over Pd@NHCS. The strong EMSI between pyridinic N and Pd sites enhanced the electron density of active Pd centers and promoted the adsorption and activation of vanillin and H2 on the catalyst surface. During the tandem HDO reaction process, vanillin was firstly readily adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, whose –C=O group became promptly activated by the electron-rich active Pd sites. Meanwhile, the dissociation and activation of H2 molecules quickly proceeded under the catalysis of active Pd sites, which generated large numbers of active hydrogen species, leading to the hydrogenation of vanillin to the intermediate of VA. Subsequently, the –C–O group of VA molecule preferentially oriented and broke under the attack of active hydrogen species, and finally produced the target MMP along with a water molecule. Owing to the hydrophobicity of MMP, it could rapidly detach from the catalyst surface and make the active sites fully exposed to the hydrophilic vanillin and the H2 molecules, thus realizing the highly efficient HDO of vanillin to produce value-added MMP. As for the tandem vanillin HDO reaction, the continuous electron transfer from pyridinic N to Pd increased the electron density of active Pd centers and ensured the Pd@NHCS catalyst was highly active and selective for the HDO of vanillin in water. 3.6 Scalability and substrate scope of Pd@NHCS catalyst Because of the advantages in composition and structure, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented superior catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability for vanillin HDO in the green solvent of water. Notably, the efficient catalytic performance of the Pd@NHCS-600 has been validated in the tenfold scale-up experiment of vanillin HDO (Scheme 1 ), where a complete conversion of vanillin with 100% MMP yield was achieved under the mild reaction conditions, implying the great potential of practical application in biomass refining. In addition to the scalability, the versatility of Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst was investigated in the catalytic HDO of various biomass-derived aldehyde and ketone derivates containing different functional groups. As shown in Table 3 , the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the selective HDO of various lignin-derived model compounds. For instance, a series of lignin-derived model compounds of o-vanillin, ethylvanillin, isovanillin, anisic aldehyde, and benzaldehyde (entries 2–6), could be selectively converted to the corresponding decarbonyl products through the hydrodeoxygenation of –C=O group under the optimized reaction conditions while kept other reducible groups chemically inert. As for the typical biomass-derived aldehyde compounds of cinnamaldehyde and furfural (entries 7, 8), they could also be efficiently and selectively transformed into the desired HDO products under mild reaction conditions. Apart from the biomass-derived aldehydes, the –C=O groups of aromatic ketones such as acetophenone and 4-hydroxyacetophenone might realize the highly selective HDO to accordingly produce ethylbenzene and p-hydroxye- thylbenzene within the aqueous solution (entries 9, 10). As compared with the aromatic ketones, the representative aliphatic ketones including acetone, 2-hexanone and cyclohexanone could be readily converted to the corresponding alkane products with high selectivity through the HDO of –C=O bonds under the much milder reaction condition (entries 11–13). These results highlighted the exceptional catalytic efficiency and broad applicability of Pd@NHCS catalyst in the highly selective HDO of biomass-derived carbonyl compounds. 4 Conclusions In summary, an innovative surface microenvironment modulation strategy was used to construct a series of Pd@NHCS-X (X = 600–800) nanoreactors, which could serve as highly active and stable metal catalysts for aqueous phase HDO of vanillin. The specific surface microenvironments of Pd@NHCS catalysts including the electronic property of active Pd centers and the surface wettability and porous structure of NHCS support could be well-controlled by the calcination temperature of catalysts. The optimized Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst displayed the complete vanillin conversion with 100% selectivity towards MMP under the mild reaction conditions of 120 °C, 0.1 MPa H2, and 6 h using water as solvent. Intrinsic kinetic evaluations further demonstrated the superior catalytic performance of the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst, which presented the highest TOF value of 337.77 h–1 and the lowest apparent activation energy of 18.63 kJ/mol among various Pd@NHCS-X catalysts. Thorough structure characterization confirmed that the synthesized Pd@NHCS catalysts exhibited suitable hydrophilicity and abundant porous structure. It facilitated the homogeneous dispersion of Pd@NHCS catalyst in the aqueous medium and promoted the effective access of reactant molecules to catalytic active sites. Moreover, the calcination temperature of catalysts could regulate the type and content of surface nitrogen species of NHCS support. The substantial electronic metal-support interaction between Pd sites and pyridinic N species of NHCS support was formed in the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst, which could enhance surface electron density of Pd sites and produce electron-rich active Pd centers, thus promoting the adsorption and activation of vanillin and H2 molecules based on the structure-activity relationship studies. DFT calculations further confirmed the dominant role of pyridinic N species in modulating the electron property of active Pd centers through the EMSI effect, and the advantage of pyridinic N species guided Pd centers in promoting the adsorption and activation of reactants. Accordingly, the catalytic reaction mechanism of vanillin HDO over the Pd@NHCS catalyst was proposed. Furthermore, the optimal Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented excellent catalytic stability during the five consecutive runs. Additionally, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst is highly versatile for the selective HDO of various biomass-derived carbonyl compounds under the aqueous phase reaction conditions. This work not only demonstrated the great importance of surface microenvironment modulation in promoting the catalytic HDO performance of encapsulated Pd NPs, but also provided a new consideration for the rational design of high-performance nitrogen-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts for sustainable catalytic transformation of biomass. coredata.dc:description: Development of efficient and stable metal catalysts for the selective aqueous phase hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of biomass-derived oxygenates to value-added biofuels is highly desired. An innovative surface microenvironment modulation strategy was used to construct the nitrogen-doped hollow carbon sphere encapsulated with Pd (Pd@NHCS-X, X: 600–800) nanoreactors for catalytic HDO of biomass-derived vanillin in water. The specific surface microenvironments of Pd@NHCS catalysts including the electronic property of active Pd centers and the surface wettability and porous structure of NHCS supports could be well-controlled by the calcination temperature of catalysts. Intrinsic kinetic evaluations demonstrated that the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst presented a high turnover frequency of 337.77 h–1 and a low apparent activation energy of 18.63 kJ/mol. The excellent catalytic HDO performance was attributed to the unique surface microenvironment of Pd@NHCS catalyst based on structure-performance relationship analysis and DFT calculations. It revealed that pyridinic N species dominated the electronic property regulation of Pd sites through electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) and produced numerous electron-rich active Pd centers, which not only intensified the dissociation and activation of H2 molecules, but also substantially improved the activation capability of vanillin via the enhanced adsorption of –C=O group. The fine hydrophilicity and abundant porous structure promoted the uniform dispersion of catalyst and ensured the effective access of reactants to catalytic active centers in water. Additionally, the Pd@NHCS-600 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic stability and broad substrate applicability for the selective aqueous phase HDO of various biomass-derived carbonyl compounds. The proposed surface microenvironment modulation strategy will provide a new consideration for the rational design of high- performance nitrogen-doped carbon-supported metal catalysts for catalytic biomass transformation.
